 I. 

THE PROPOSAL 

 
1. 
I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on a proposed equity 
investment  of  up  to  $50,000,000  in  Clifford  Capital  Holdings  Pte.  Ltd.  (CCH)  for  the  Asian 
Sustainable  Infrastructure  Mobilization  Project. 1  The  report  also  describes  the  proposed 
administration of an equity investment of up to $45,000,000 to be provided by the Leading Asia’s 
Private Infrastructure Fund (LEAP), and if the Board approves the proposed equity investment, I, 
acting under the authority delegated to me by the Board, approve the administration of the equity 
investment. 2 
 
2. 
CCH is raising equity capital from new and existing shareholders to be drawn from 2020 
to  2024  to  scale  up  its  investments  in  sustainable  infrastructure  through  the  expansion  of  two 
existing  group  companies—Clifford  Capital  Pte.  Ltd.  (CCPL)  and  Pierfront  Capital  Fund 
Management Pte. Ltd. (Pierfront)—and the establishment of two new group companies—Bayfront 
Infrastructure Management Pte. Ltd. (BIM) and a supply chain financing (SCF) entity.3 The equity 
investment of the Asian Development Bank (ADB) of up to $95 million will secure a board seat for 
ADB at CCH. 4 CCH’s other existing shareholders include Temasek, Standard Chartered Bank, 
DBS  Bank,  Sumitomo  Mitsui  Banking  Corporation  (SMBC),  Prudential  Assurance  Company 
Singapore (Pte) Limited, and John Hancock.5 
 

II. 

THE FINANCIAL INTERMEDIARY 

Investment Identification and Description 

 
A. 
 
Developing Asia will require annual infrastructure investments of $1.7 trillion  to 2030 to 
3. 
sustain economic growth and effectively combat climate change.6 Presently, 70% of infrastructure 
investment in Asia is financed by the public sector, which is unsustainable if developing Asia's 
infrastructure  financing  needs  are  to  be  met.7 Moreover,  as  governments  are  allocating  public 
funds for emergency response and relief efforts related to the coronavirus disease (COVID-19) 
pandemic, there will be a greater reliance on private sector funding to close the infrastructure gap 
in  developing  Asia.  In  the  private  sector  in  Asia,  infrastructure  financing  is  dominated  by 
commercial banks, export credit agencies, infrastructure funds, pension funds, and development 
finance  institutions  (DFIs).  However,  the  implementation  of  Basel  III,  with  its  stricter  capital 
adequacy requirements, will limit the lending capacity of commercial banks, thus increasing the 
challenge of obtaining long-term financing for infrastructure projects. The rise of funds focused on 
providing  debt  and  equity  for  infrastructure  assets,  as  well  as  increasing  financial  innovation 
through securitization, can help to address some of these financing needs. CCH, through its four 
complementary  group  companies  and  their  origination  and  distribution  platforms,  provides 
commercial financing for infrastructure and real assets, which is expected to catalyze and attract 
long-term institutional capital to this underserved market segment in Asia.

5. 
CCPL  was  established  with  support  from  the  Government  of  Singapore  to  provide 
commercially-driven  project  finance  and  structured  finance  solutions  to  Singapore-based 
companies  that  invest  equity  in,  or  provide  services  or  equipment  to,  infrastructure,  offshore

portfolio  to  $1.9  billion  as  of  September  2019.  In  2016,  CCPL  supported  the  establishment  of 
Pierfront  Capital,  a  private  credit  fund  manager,  which  provides  mezzanine  financing  for 
infrastructure  and  real  assets.  In  2018,  CCPL,  through  Bayfront  Infrastructure  Capital, 
successfully closed  a  $458  million  inaugural  securitization  of  project  and  infrastructure finance 
loans from Asia, drawing institutional capital from 16 investors globally. In March 2020, existing 
CCPL shareholders have swapped their shareholding in CCPL for new shares in CCH. CCH is 
raising  additional  capital  from  new,  strategic  investors  to  fund  its  future  growth  plans.  ADB’s 
investment will support CCH’s growth in sustainable infrastructure financing in developing Asia.

18. 
ADB will monitor the project throughout its duration. CCH will provide ADB with financial 
reports at predetermined regular intervals, including (i) annual audited financial statements, (ii) 
quarterly  reports  to  its  board  and  shareholders,  (iii)  annual  reports  on  selected  development

C. 
 
19. 
Support  sustainable  and  inclusive  growth  as  a  strategic  shareholder.  ADB  will  be 
CCH’s  first  multilateral  investor  and  will  provide  patient  capital  for  CCH’s  growth.  As  a  Board 
member, ADB will provide strategic inputs into CCH’s business plan(s) to drive CCH’s operations 
towards more inclusive and sustainable infrastructure development in ADB’s developing member 
countries  (DMCs).  ADB’s  strong  network  of  clients,  government  relationships,  technical 
assistance  and  project  preparation  capabilities,  as  well  as  cofinancing  partners  will  help  CCH 
substantially  increase  its  share  of  sustainable  infrastructure  assets  in  ADB’s  DMCs  through 
identifying, structuring, financing, and implementing bankable projects. In addition, while ADB’s 
equity  capital  will  directly  contribute towards  increasing  CCH’s  ability  to leverage and  mobilize 
private  investments  in  frontier  markets  and  emerging  sectors,  it  will  also  indirectly  contribute, 
through the multiplier effect, towards job creation and ADB’s climate targets in its DMCs. 
 
20. 
Enhance  mobilization  through  cofinancing  opportunities.  As  long-term  private 
funding for infrastructure is becoming even more constrained during the COVID-19 crisis in Asia, 
ADB’s anchor investment is needed not only to build CCH’s long-term capital base but also to 
boost investor confidence and mobilizations amid market dislocations. CCH will gain unparalleled 
access  to  potential  cofinancing  and  co-investment  opportunities  with  ADB.  [CONFIDENTIAL 
INFORMATION DELETED] By cofinancing alongside ADB in emerging countries (Group A or B 
countries) and sectors (such as renewable energy and environmental infrastructure), CCH can 
develop  newfound  market  or  sector  expertise  and  invest  on  its  own  or  mobilize  other  private 
investors  in  the  future. 14  Further,  through  ADB’s  resident  missions,  including  the  newly

DEVELOPMENT IMPACT AND STRATEGIC ALIGNMENT 

Development Impact, Outcome, and Outputs 

 
A. 
 
The project is aligned with Sustainable Development Goal 8.10 as it will strengthen the 
28. 
capacity of domestic financial institutions to encourage and expand access to banking, insurance, 
and  financial  services  for  all. 17  The  project  will  have  the  following  outcome:  private  sector

million of ADB equity capital raised and sustainably invested in low-carbon infrastructure projects 
in ADB’s DMCs, and partly in Group A or B countries; and (iii) gender inclusivity at CCH improved. 
 
B. 
 
In  line  with  ADB’s  Strategy  2030,  this  project  supports  ADB’s  focus  on  mobilizing  and

transport,  and  information  and  communication  technology. 20  This  is  also  aligned  with  the

private  sector  investment  and  growth.  Through  a  collaborative  One  ADB  approach  involving 
ADB’s regional departments, Office of Public–Private Partnership, and Sustainable Development 
and  Climate  Change  Department,  ADB  aims  to  accelerate  and  increase  private  sector 
investments in many of its frontier markets and sectors. 
 
31. 
This  regional  project  strongly  supports  operational  priority  7  (fostering  regional 
cooperation  and  integration),  as  it  expands  global  and  regional  investment  opportunities  in 
infrastructure in Asia. The establishment of CCH is part of the Government of Singapore’s regional 
initiative to support Asia’s social and economic growth through infrastructure development, with 
Singapore  as  the  regional  infrastructure  development  hub.  CCPL’s  current  portfolio  comprises 
several cross-border infrastructure projects, exemplifying regional cooperation among financiers, 
borrowers, and sponsors located across multiple countries in Asia. This project aligns with other 
regional ADB initiatives such as the partnership between Infrastructure Asia and ADB to promote 
innovative and green financing for sustainable infrastructure in Southeast Asia.21 Through CCH’s 
current  investments  in  ports,  shipping,  transport,  and  information  and  communications 
technology, this project also promotes higher-quality connectivity and integration within Asia. 
 
32. 
The  project  supports  operational  priority  1  (addressing  remaining  poverty  and  reducing 
inequalities) as it aims to increase private investments in some of the poorest and most vulnerable 
ADB DMCs. The lack of capital flows, especially private sector financing, into such countries slows 
poverty alleviation and economic growth. Through ADB’s investment, CCH will commit to making 
at  least  two  additional  investments  in  Group  A  or  B  countries,  thereby  bringing  private  sector 
financing and opportunities to the most vulnerable countries and communities. 
 
33. 
The project supports operational priority 3 (tackling climate change, building climate and 
disaster  resilience,  and  enhancing  environmental  sustainability)  as  CCH  aims  to  expand 
investments in renewables. In line with the Government of Singapore’s strategy of becoming a 
pioneer  in  green  financing,  Singapore's  central  bank  has  announced  a  $2  billion  green 
investments program to drive growth in sustainable finance, which CCH will be able to support.22 
The project will contribute to ADB’s climate financing target of $80 billion cumulatively from 2019 
to 2030; $30 million of ADB’s own resources will finance climate mitigation investments. 23 
 
34. 
This project also promotes ADB’s operational priority 2 (accelerating progress in gender 
equality) by enhancing women’s participation and access to decision-making and leadership roles 
within CCH. CCH will commit to offering professional skills and leadership training to its female 
staff and increasing the representation of women in management and decision-making roles.
